One member in this group loans has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy wood to make more cabinets to sell

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: V. is 53 years old and lives in the Pursat Province. She makes a living with her husband in growing rice and vegetable crops. They have been cultivating for a long time, and make an income of approximately $5 per day. Besides this, Mrs. V. sells Khmer cakes at a location near the Vat Loung Pagoda. She is also a mother of three children, all three of whom are single. One of her sons is employed as a rice mill worker, while the other two are attending school. Since cultivating is a main source of income for the family, V. has applied for a loan to buy two cows to help her plow her farmland and to raise its offspring.

loans.use: To buy two cows to help her plow her farmland

loans.name: Yoeng

texts.en: Yoeng Y. is 40 years old, married and lives with her husband, their five children and her mother in Bati district, Takeo province. She is a weaver and makes about US$5 of profit per day. She and her mother also grow vegetables to sell in the local market. Two of her children are in school, while three others are farmers. Mrs. Yoeng Y. is requesting a loan to purchase more silk with which to weave scarves.

loans.use: To purchase silk.

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Mr. Thy U. is a farmer in Lvea village in Takeo province. He owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to cultivate rice during the dry season. In order to solve this problem, he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, fuel, and hire laborers to work on the field. His wife, Mrs. Keo Sinat, is a chicken middleman. Mr. Thy U. is 43 years old and the father of three children who are attending the local school. His wife is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, fuel, and pay laborers to work the field

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Mr. Sao S. lives in Lvea village in Takeo province. He is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Soen Nim, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. In this plantation, she faces a problem because she does not have enough money to grow rice during the dry season. Thus, Mr. Sao S. decided to ask for a loan to help his wife cultivate rice. He hopes to increase his income and improve his living conditions with this loan. He is a 29-year-old father of a child who is too young to work or study. His wife is also shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: to cultivate rice in the dry season

loans.name: Proeung

texts.en: Proeung R., 50, is a weaver who lives with her husband in Bati district, Takeo province. She typically makes $2 of profit per day, while her husband is a construction foreman in the village, making about $5 each day. The couple has four children, two who are in school and two others who are construction workers. Mrs. Proeung is requesting a loan to purchase more silk to expand her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea L., a widow, is a villager in Pong Ror village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates cassava. With this cassava-growing, she can earn a little income to support her family; thus, she wants to buy more cassava from other villagers to re-sell in order to support the family.

Mrs. Chea L. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she would use the rest of the money to hire laborers to work on her field. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. She is 57 years old and has two children, one of whom is a laborer while the other is a farmer who helps his mother with her work.

loans.use: to buy more cassava from other villagers to re-sell

loans.name: Brak

texts.en:
Brak N., 34, is married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Since 1998, she and her husband have had a business grinding rice to earn a living and are able to make $4 of profit each day. The couple has three children, two who are in school and one is too young to attend school yet.

Mrs. Brak N. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase rice to remove the husks, with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice and grind it to remove its husks

loans.name: Phou

texts.en: Phou M. is 47 years old and is a farmer living in the Prey Veng province with her husband and two children. Typically, she makes $1.50 per day while her husband makes about $7 working in construction. This couple also has received support from both their children, who work as construction workers. Phou M. is requesting a loan so that she can purchase a sewing machine for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi: Chị Bùi Thị Năm năm nay 64 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị  Năm là tư buôn bán hàng tạp hóa và chăn nuôi, trồng trọt với tổng thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị Năm mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn mua thêm cac loại hàng tạp hóa, bánh mứt, kẹo để phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu dùng của bà con trong dịp Tết sắp tới.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bùi Thị Năm, 64 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2003. Currently, the main sources of income for Mrs. Năm’s family are a grocery shop, raising animals, and farming, with a total monthly income of 5,000,000 VND (300 USD). In the next lending cycle, Mrs. Năm hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (900 USD) to increase her inventory of groceries, sweet cakes, and candy in order to meet the needs of her customers during the Tet holiday season.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Korn

texts.en: Korn S. is 28 years old and runs a business making rice wine from her home. She typically makes about $1.50 per day. Meanwhile, her husband operates a moto-taxi and is able to make $4 everyday. This couple has three children, two of whom are in school and one who is too young to attend the school. Mrs. Korn is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike so that her husband can improve his taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for taxi business

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mr. M. is aged 62. His wife's name is Pouv and she is 59 years old.  Both are residents of Pursat Province, Cambodia.  They are local cultivators growing things like rice, cabbage, morning glories, and Chines Kale.  They currently make an income of around $6 per day to provide the family's foods. 

The couple has nine children; seven of them are married and the others are single.  Two of their children are employed as farmers.  

Mr. M. is applying for a loan to buy a motorcycle to use for family riding, and a water buffalo to help his physical labor in plowing farmland. 

(Mr. M.'s wife is pictured because he was not available.)

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to use for family riding and a water buffalo for plowing

loans.name: Doan Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đoàn Thị Hồng  năm nay 58 tuổi, chị  hiện đang sống cùng chồng  và  1 con đã trưởng thành. Năm 1999 chị Hồng tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán nhỏ, đến nay sau 10 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương chị đã là chủ một của hàng kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa tại chợ.  Hiện tại ngoài thu nhập từ buôn bán gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng nên kinh tế ngày càng ổn định hơn với thu nhập 4.5000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị Hồng mong muốn được vay 12.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn mua thêm cac laọi hàng tạp hóa, bánh mứt, kẹo để phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu dùng của bà con trong dịp Tết sắp tới.
texts.en:
Mrs. Đoàn Thị Hồng, 58 years old, lives with her husband and one grown child. In 1999, Mrs. Hồng became a member of the TYM Fund and used a loan to start a small retail enterprise selling miscellaneous items. Today, after participating in the Fund for ten years, she has become the owner of a grocery shop located beside her town’s open-air market. Currently, her husband receives a small retirement pension, which supplements the family’s earnings from the shop, so that their financial situation is steadily improving. Their total income is about 4,500,000 VND (270 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, Mrs. Hồng hopes to borrow 12,000,000 VND (725 USD) to increase her inventory of groceries, sweet cakes, and candy, in order to meet the needs of her customers during the Tet holiday season.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm C. is 26 years old and married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She stays at home doing housework and cooks for her family members. Her husband is self-employed as a construction foreman, earning around $7 per day. She and her husband have one young child. Morm C. is currently requesting a loan to purchase tools for her husband business.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun O. is 52 years old, pictured on the right hand side, and lives with her husband and four children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She runs a shop at her home selling grocery products to the people in her community, earning around $5 per day. 

Meanwhile, her husband is a pig trader and makes about $10 each day. In addition two of her children are garment factory workers, earning $2 each a day. Her other children are in school. This loan will be used to help her husband buy more pigs to operate his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional pigs for her husband's pig business

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hoàng Thị Huyền  năm nay 23 tuổi, chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng  làm nghề lái xe và  1 con nhỏ tại  Thị Trấn Lâm huyện Ý Yên tỉnh Nam Định.Trước khi tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị rất khó khăn do thu nhập chủ yếu của gia đình chỉ dựa vào lương của chồng. Năm 2005 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn dể đầu tư vào buôn bán hàng tạp hóa. Hiện tại với tổng thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng cuộc sống của gia đình chị dang ngày càng được cải thiện hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị Huyền mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoàng Thị Huyền, 23 years old, lives with her husband and one young child in the town of Lâm, Ý Yên district, Nam Định province. Her husband works as a driver. Before she became a member of the TYM Fund, the financial situation of her family was very difficult because their income depended solely on her husband’s wages. In 2005, she joined the Fund and used a loan to invest in a grocery shop. Today, with an income of 4,000,000 VND (240 USD) per month, her family’s standard of living is steadily improving. In the next lending cycle, Mrs. Huyền hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (600 USD) to increase the inventory of her grocery shop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Kann

texts.en: Kann S. is 46 years old and a mother of three school-aged children. They all live in Prey Veng, Cambodia. She and her husband are grocery vendors, working from their home, earning about $4 each day. She plans to invest in additional grocery products so that she can meet her customers' needs.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery inventories

loans.name: Ninh Thi

texts.vi: Chị Ninh Thị Lâm 56 tuổi, chồng chị không may mất sớm, hiện tại chị đang sống cùng hai con đã trưởng thành. Năm 2001 chị  Lâm tham gia Quỹ tình thương để vay vốn đầu tư phát triển nghề mộc tạo công ăn việc làm cho các con. Đến nay say  7 năm tham gia quỹ tình thương với nguồn thu nhập ổn định từ chăn nuôi và làm mộc cuộc sống của gia đình chị Lâm đã được cải thiện đáng kể với thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị Lâm mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 đ để đầu tư mua gỗ phục vụ cho việc sản xuất của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ninh Thị Lâm, 56 years old, lives with two grown children. Unfortunately, her husband passed away at an early age. In 2001, Mrs. Lâm became a member of the TYM Fund and used a loan to develop a woodworking enterprise in order to provide employment for her children. Today, after seven years of participation in the Fund, with income from both their woodworking business and raising animals, the lives of Mrs. Lâm and her family have greatly improved. Their monthly income is about 4,000,000 VND (240 USD). In the next lending cycle, Mrs. Lâm hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (600 USD) to buy wood for their family woodworking business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Woodworking shop

loans.name: Dith

texts.en:
Mrs. Dith L. is married with six children. Four of her children are in school and two are too young to attend the school. She lives in Prey Veng, Cambodia with her family, including her husband. She and her husband run a business of grinding rice crops. 

From this business activity, she generally makes around $4 of profit everyday. This couple hopes to use this loan to expand their current rice stock. She will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning it over for a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living. (She is pictured with her husband and her children)

loans.use: To purchase rice and expand her current rice inventory

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Phương năm nay 44 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và ba con tại huyện Ý  Yên tỉnh  Nam Định. Trước khi tham gia quỹ tình thương  thu nhập của gia đình chị Phương chủ yếu là từ thu mua phế liệu.  Năm 1998 chị Phương đã tham gia quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá và chăn nuôi cá. Công việc phát triển tốt và đem lại cho gia đình chị nguồn thu nhập ổn định. Hiện tại bên cạnh thu nhập từ buôn bán và  nuôi cá gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu từ việc đi đúc đồng thuê của chồng với tổng thu  nhập bình quân 4.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu  tư kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa và mua cá giống về nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Phương, 44 years old, lives with her husband and three children in Ý Yên district, Nam Định province. Before she became a member of the TYM Fund, her family’s income came mainly from collecting scrap materials. In 1998, she joined the Fund and used a loan to start a small grocery shop and a fish farming enterprise. The operations have thrived and now provide her family with a steady income. Currently, in addition to the family businesses selling groceries and raising fish, her husband also earns wages working in a bronze casting business. The family income averages about 4,000,000 VND (240 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (900 USD) to invest in her grocery shop and to buy fish to stock her fish farming operation.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop, Fish farming

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan C. is 23 years old and lives with her husband and one child in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She stays at home doing housework and cooks for her family members. Her husband currently earns $5 a day by operating a moto-taxi around the village market. Phan would like this loan so that she can replace an old and unreliable bike with a new, reliable one for her husband to run as a taxi. The old bike is fixed much too often and uses a lot of gas when the motor is operating. (Phan is pictured with her husband and her kid)

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for her husband's taxi business

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Chuon S. is 40 years old and lives in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. To earn income for her family, she grows rice and many other kinds of vegetables and sells it to the market. As a result, she earns around $2 each day. 

Her husband is a police officer and makes approximately $3 a day. She and her husband have three children, all of whom are in school. Mrs. Chuon S. is humbly requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation needs. This bike will be used to transport rice and for her husband to commute to work as well.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to help the family commute to and from work and school.

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en:
L. has been selling a variety of grocery products out of her house for more than 9 years.  She sells the items like cooked ingredients, plastic products, canned foods and sweets for villagers and passers-by.  She can earn around $4 per day from her investment. 

She is aged 29 and is married to Mr. Sophat who is 32 years old and currently works as an ambulance driver for a hospital, and as a rice farmer.  They, together, are responsible for their two children; both of them are teenagers and go to school. 

L.'s investment is going well in that a lot of customers buy her wares.  To earn extra income and to progress her investment, L. is asking for a loan to buy more grocery inventory to store and later re-sell.  

L. lives in Pursat Province and she and her children are pictured.

loans.use: To buy more grocery inventory to store and later re-sell

loans.name: Chheung

texts.en:
Chheung S. is 55 years old and resides in the Prey Veng province with her husband and two of her children. She grows and sells rice to earn approximately $1 of profit each day. 

Her husband had been retired from work for a year and currently receives $1 per day for his retirement. Two of their children are employed and share the income to help raise their standard of living as well. Mrs. Chheung is asking for a loan so that she can purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a moto-taxi and increase the family's well-being.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to operate a taxi business

loans.name: San

texts.en: San N. is 42 years old and lives with her four nieces in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been selling grocery products to earn a living and is able to make about US$3 of profit everyday. She hopes to use this loan to purchase more grocery items to satisfy her clients.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Sáng năm nay 58 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2002. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị  Sáng là tư buôn bán hàng tạp hóa và chăn nuôi, trồng trọt với tổng thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị Sáng mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn mua thêm các loại hàng tạp hóa, bánh mứt, kẹo để phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu dùng của bà con trong dịp Tết sắp tới.
texts.en:
Ms. Nguyễn Thị Sáng is 59 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2002. Currently, Ms. Sáng's family's income of 4,000,000 VND per month comes mainly from the retailing of general goods, rearing of livestock and growing rice. For this loan cycle, Ms. Sáng hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND to purchase more goods to sell for the Tet celebrations.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more goods to sell.

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
S. is a 31 year old woman who currently takes care of her two small children.  Both of them are young and are enrolled in school.  

She owns and runs a stall next to her house raising pigs, which she sells to slaughterer after they mature.  

She is married to San, 37 years old, who is a local teacher teaching pupils in the primary school.  The family lives in Pursat Province. 

Mrs. S. plans to buy more piglets to raise, but she lacks the money to do that.  To achieve the goal, she would like to request a loan of $600 as capital to purchase more piglets to raise. 

(S.'s husband appears in the photo because she was not available for photographing.)

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
S. is a villager who lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia.  He makes a living as a local crop grower, growing vegetables, rice and some fruit trees that he can grow during both seasons including the dry season and rainy season.

He is married and the good father of two children: one child is a teenager and attends school, while the other is a lovely baby.  Whilst his wife assists him in growing crops, she also raises pigs from home for sale. 

S. faces difficulties watering crops; thus, he is asking for a loan to purchase a pump to irrigate his crops.  The remaining loan will be used to buy more piglets to raise. 

(S.'s wife is pictured because he was not available that day.)

loans.use: To purchase a pump to irrigate his crops and more piglets to raise

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila is a 57-year-old woman who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon with her husband. Laila has owned a clothing shop since 2004, where she also sells perfumes, accessories, and other products. Laila sells quality products and understands the importance of being respectful to her clients, who are her friends and neighbors. When she first started this business, she didn’t have enough start up capital.

She requested a loan of 800 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is the first time that Laila has requested a loan. In the future, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
C. was born 1973 and lives with five other family members in a small family home in the Pursat Province.  She and her husband make a living as rice cultivators.  The couple currently has four children; all four of them are single and in school. 

To help meet the family's food needs, C.'s husband is a motorcycle taxi driver, and he provides a service to passengers for a profit.  

In view of the fact that rice cultivating is the main source of income for the family, and to help with the physical labors, C. and her husband are applying for a loan to purchase water buffalo to use for plowing their farmland. 

(C.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase water buffalo to use for plowing their farmland

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Benkadi  de l’association Dèmè sont  au nombre de quatre (04)  et ont en moyenne 39 ans et 4 enfants. Toutes mariées elles vivent dans des grandes familles polygamiques dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Les membres du groupe se sont connus à travers les activités de petit commerce des condiments alimentaires qu’elles mènent au marché château de Ségou.
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant de la clientèle elles ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Elles sont à leur 4ème prêt, après avoir correctement remboursé les prêts précédents. 
Ce prêt  sera  utilisé pour acheter, 3 bidons de 20litres d’huile, 1 carton de cubes maggie, 3 cartons de laye, 1 carton de soumbala (condiment préparé à base de noix de néré ou du fruit de soja) et 40kgs de poissons fumés. Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments à Bamako généralement et en poisson fumé au grand marché de Ségou. Elles revendent leurs produits au marché château de Ségou au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles réalisent un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 42 900 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser le prêt, payer les tontines et le savon. Leur ambition est de  devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The members of this Benkadi group, belonging to the Dèmè association, are four women who have an average age of 39 and, on average, 4 children. They are all married and live in big polygamous families in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

The members of this group came to know each other because they are all petty traders selling condiments in the "Château" market of Ségou. With the goal of satisfying the ever-growing needs of their clientele, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. They are on their 4th loan, after having correctly reimbursed the preceding loans.

This loan will be used to buy 3 jerry cans of 20 liters of oil, 1 case of Maggi cubes, 3 cases of garlic, 1 case of "soumbala" (a condiment prepared using "néré" tree seeds or soya) and 40 kg of smoked fish. They generally buy their condiments in Bamako and their smoked fish at the big open-air market of Ségou. They sell their products at the "Château" marketplace in Ségou, for cash or on credit, to a clientele composed mostly of women.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 42,900 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan, make payments to their association's savings program, and buy soap. Their ambition is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments and smoked fish for re-sale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les huit (08) membres du groupe Benkadi  de l’association Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées et vivent dans des grandes familles polygames avec en moyenne 40 ans et 5 enfants. Ils résident dans le village de Zogofina préfecture de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de mariage dans le village.
Dans le souci de développer leur activité, ces femmes ont décidés d’intégrer le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursé tous les précédents.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 233 sacs de charbon de bois et 33 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elles se  ravitaillent en charbon et bois dans les villages de Tièbléna, Zenguena, Songnebougou et Sakebougou ; Parfois les producteurs de charbon viennent les ravitailler sur place au village. En plus de ces deux produits certaines femmes du groupe font aussi la vente des calebasses, du mil et du riz dans  les villages environnants et le marché de Médine Ségou. Quant au charbon de bois et au bois de chauffe, ils sont écoulés  dans les charrettes en ambulant à travers les différents quartiers de Ségou  ou à domicile au village au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle composée  d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 51 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The eight members of this Benkadi group, belonging to the association Djiguissèmè, are all married and live in big polygamous families. They have an average age of 40 and on average, 5 children. They live in the village of Zogofina, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other because they are neighbors in their village or are related.

In the intention of developing their businesses, these women decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are presently on their 5th solidarity loan, after having correctly reimbursed all the preceding loans. This loan will be used to buy 233 sacks of charcoal and 33 wagon loads of firewood. They buy the charcoal and the firewood in the villages of Tièbléna, Zenguena, Songnebougou, and Sakebougou. Sometimes the charcoal makers come to deliver directly to them in their village. Besides these two products, some of the women in the group also sell gourds, millet, and rice in the surrounding villages and the market of Médine Ségou. They sell the charcoal and the firewood, transporting it in wagons, going door-to-door in the various neighborhoods of Ségou or they sell right at their homes, for cash and on credit, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They hope to make an average monthly profit of 51,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to contribute to supporting their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy charcoal and firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo Y. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer and typically makes $1 each day. Meanwhile, her husband, pictured here, runs a business as cow dealer, earning up to $2 a day. Mrs Keo Y. will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and rice seed for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and rice for her rice farm

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun K., 62 years old, is married and works together with her husband in Prey Veng province. They grow and sell rice that generates about US$4 each day for the family. They work very hard at the field and need to purchase additional fertilizers and rice seed to expand their cultivation. 

Hun K. is asking for US$300 to purchase fertilizers. They see this as a profitable venture that will not only increase their income, but also raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and rice seed to expand their crop inventories

loans.name: Djèmakan (Consensus) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (04) membres du groupe Djèmakan ont un âge moyen de 38 ans, toutes mariées elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 4 enfants à Markala préfecture de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ce groupe de femme fait de la fabrication des boissons locales non alcoolisées et  de temps à autre de la restauration à base de la pomme de terre.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle elles ont décidé  d’adhérer au  programme de crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème prêt.
 Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 sacs de gingembre, 100kg d’oseille de Guinée , 20 flacons d’essence, 1 sac de citron, 2 paniers de tamarins et 2 sacs de sucre. Les jus d’oseille de Guinée et de gingembre sont des boissons de fabrication locales préparées à partir du mélange de ces produits locaux précités. Elles se  ravitaillent une fois par quinzaine à la foire de Diamarabougou Markala.
Tous ces produits sont vendus à domicile et en ambulant à une cliente constituée d’hommes et de femmes à Markala. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les prêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses personnelles. Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter un congélateur.
texts.en:
The four members of the Djèmakan group have an average age of 38. They are all married and live in polygamous families with on average 4 children in Markala, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

These women prepare traditional local drinks (non-alcoholic) and sometimes sell cooked food made out of potatoes. In order to satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their third loan.

This loan will be used to buy 2 sacks of ginger, 100 kg of hibiscus flowers, 20 bottles of flavoring, 1 sack of lemons, 2 baskets of tamarinds, and 2 sacks of sugar. Hibiscus flower and ginger juice are locally prepared drinks made by mixing the above-mentioned local products. They stock up once every two weeks at the market fair of Diamarabougou Markala. All these products are sold at their homes and door-to-door to a clientele consisting of men and women in Markala. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 25,500 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and cover personal expenses. Their ambition is to be able to buy a freezer.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ginger, hiciscus flower, and sugar

loans.name: Che

texts.en: Che S., 58, lives with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. She is a housewife and has to take care of her two school-aged children, while her other one is a policeman, earning up to $2 a day. Additionally, her husband is self-employed as taxi-driver earning $15 in revenue each day. Mrs Che S. will use the loan to purchase a car for her husband to operate a taxi.

loans.use: To run a taxi.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Mr. Phan S. is a villager in Knol village in Kampong Cham province. He is a furniture maker. His wife, Mrs. Dy Hean, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates both rice and cassava. With her cassava farming, she earns a little income to support her family. <>

Thus, Mr. Phan S. decided to request a loan to buy more cassava to re-sell and hire laborers to work in his wife’s business. Mr. Phan S. is 47 years old and the father of four children, two of whom are farmers who help their mother with her work while the others are enrolled in the local school. His wife is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more cassava to re-sell and hire laborers to work in his wife’s business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Djiguissémè Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djiguissémè ont en moyenne 27 ans et 3 enfants. Elles sont toutes mariées  et vivent dans des familles polygamiques dans le village de Zogofina, préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région de la république de Mali). 
Les membres du groupe se sont connus à travers des liens de mariage et de voisinage dans le village. Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers les femmes de Zogofina Wêrê qui mènent les mêmes activités génératrices de revenus qu’elles et qui sont dans le système depuis plusieurs années. Fascinées par la modalité de remboursement elles se sont organisées pour intégrer le programme crédit depuis maintenant 3 ans. Elles sont actuellement à leur 5ème prêt  après avoir correctement remboursé les précédents. 
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 7 sacs de riz et 38  chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elles s’approvisionnent en riz à la foire hebdomadaire du grand marché de Ségou et en bois de chauffe à Songnebougou et à Bounoubougoula. Le riz est revendu au marché de Médine et à domicile au village alors que l’écoulement du  bois de chauffe se vend en ambulant à travers Ségou au comptant, en détail et à crédit  à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 32 500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser le prêt,  la prise en charge alimentaire et le prix du pétrole pour les études des enfants.
texts.en:
The members of this Djiguissémè group have an average age of 27 and on average 3 children. They are all married and live in polygamous families in the village of Zogofina, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group know each other because they are neighbors in the village or are related to each other by marriage. They learned of Soro Yiriwaso from the women of Zogofina Wêrê who are in the same businesses as they are and have been in the system for several years. Fascinated by the process of loan reimbursement, they managed to join the loan program 3 years ago. They are currently on their 5th loan, after having reimbursed the preceding ones correctly.

This loan will be used to buy 7 sacks of rice and 38 wagon loads of firewood. They buy their rice at the weekly fair at the big open-air market of Ségou and their firewood in Songnebougou and Bounoubougoula. The rice is sold in the marketplace in Médine and out of their homes in the village, whereas the firewood is sold door-to-door around Ségou for cash, retail, and on credit to a clientele composed mainly of women.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 32,500 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan, pay for food and kerosene and for their children's school fees.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rice and firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S. is 28 years old and lives with her husband in Prey Veng, Cambodia. She and her husband have run a grocery store from home since 2007 and are able to make from this activity around $10 every day. This couple has two school-aged children. Mrs. Keo would like to take out this loan to expand her grocery store by adding more products to meet her clients' needs.

loans.use: To expand grocery store.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is married to Lucas Che, and they are blessed with two children. They live in a three-room house in the Alabukam, district in Mankon, Bamenda, NW region in Cameroon. Mama Julia has decided to work extra hard to assist her husband in catering for such a big family. She has faced many challenges in life such as the death of so many members of her family, inadequate funds to sustain her business project, and ill health. These challenges made life uncomfortable for her, until December 12th 1999 when she discovered GHAPE and became a member. In that same year, Julia received her first loan of 15,000 FRS and her repayment was successful. The profit she made was used to pay her children's school fees.

Given her loan, she plans to buy yam seedlings, cassava seedlings and proceed with the clearing of farmland. She will start repayment from the fourth month after loan disbursement. She is convinced that she will succeed because she already has a fertile piece of farmland where she will carry out her farming. And she already has experience in the activity. With the profit from the business, she plans to pay her children's school fees, using part to expand her business. She prefer to receive loans from GHAPE because of the social education GHAPE offers, and the method of repayment is convenient.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of yam seedlings, cassava seedlings and clearing of farmland

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor P., 36, is married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She has been a village teacher since 1998 and is able to make $2 per day, while her husband has a business as a cow dealer and earns around $2.50 every day. This couple has two children and they are both students. This loan will be used to purchase more cows for resale.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Faso Denignouman (Les Dignes Fils De La Nation) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Faso Denignouman sont  au nombre de six (06)  ayant en moyenne 28 ans et 4 enfants. Toutes mariées  et vivant en majorité dans des grandes familles polygamiques ces femmes résident à Markala préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Unies par des liens de voisinage et d’amitié, elles ont décidé de créer une  association «  Foutinenyelé II » qui veut dire lumière de la lampe traditionnelle pour les entraides sociales.
Ces femmes font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de poisson et des céréales. Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle elle intégra Soro Yiriwaso avec elle sont à leur  2ème prêt pour un montant de 450 000FCFA après avoir correctement remboursé leur 1er cycle. Ce prêt sera  utilisé pour acheter, 6 paniers de poissons frais, 9 sacs de riz et 21 sacs de mil. Elles s’approvisionnent en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger précisément à Kirango, en riz à Dougabougou et à Markala, en mil à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou et au marché de Kirango. Ces produits sont vendus à domicile, en ambulant et aux marchés de Kirango et de Diamarabougou (Markala) à une cliente composée de femmes et  d’hommes. Parallèlement elles sont intermédiaires entre fournisseur et d’autres acheteurs venant d’ailleurs donnant lieu à l’acquisition de recettes supplémentaires qui viennent grossir leurs fonds de commerce 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser les intérêts du prêt, acheter les médicaments, payer les frais scolaires des enfants et les tontines. Leur souhait est d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce qui leur permettra de faire des économies afin de construire une maison.
texts.en:
The 6 members of the Faso Denignouman group have an average age of 28 and on average 4 children. They are all married and most live in big polygamous families in Markala, prefecture of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Bound by ties of neighborhood and of friendship, they decided to create a traditional association « Foutinenyelé II » (meaning "the light of the lamp") for communal support.

These women basically buy and sell fish and cereals. With the goal of satisfying the needs of their customers, they joined Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their second loan in the amount of 450,000 F CFA, after having correctly reimbursed their first loan. This loan will be used to buy 6 baskets of fresh fish, 9 sacks of rice, and 21 sacks of millet. They buy their fish along the Niger river, more precisely at Kirango; their rice comes from Dougabougou and Markala, and their millet from the weekly fair at Diamarabougou and the market at Kirango. These products are sold out of their houses, or door-to-door and in the markets of Kirango and Diamarabougou (Markala) to a clientele composed of women and men. At the same time, they act as intermediaries between suppliers and buyers who come from afar, which makes a supplementary income to add to their working capital.

They hope to make a monthly average profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, to buy medicines, pay school fees for their children and pay their contributions to their communal association. Their wish is to increase their working capital which will allow them to put aside savings so as to build a house.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fish and cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan N. is 53 years old and lives with his wife in Moung Ruessei, Battambang province. He stays at home and has a business of charging batteries. People in their village depend on their batteries to power the lighting, TV and radio. His wife works growing and selling rice to both the market and wholesalers. This couple has three school-aged children. Chan N. is asking for a loan to purchase a big generator, allowing him to recharge more batteries every day.

loans.use: To purchase a big generator.

loans.name: Choam

texts.en: Choam S., 43, is married and lives in Moung Ruessei, Battambang province. He plants fruit seeds and sells the fruit to the market to earn approximately $5 every day. His wife, pictured here, opened a hairdressing salon from home and is able to earn around $8 per day. This couple has two school-aged children. Choam is asking for a loan for his wife to purchase hairdressing tools.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing tools.

loans.name: Fru Bridget

texts.en:
Bridget was born in 1973; she is a widow and the mother of four children, all of whom are below 15 years old. She lives in Ntarikom, Mankon Bamenda, Cameroon. Her husband died after a protracted illness leaving behind four children. Bridget now struggles to educate her children, clothe them, pay hospital bills, and even to provide them three square meals a day. Besides the trauma she went through after the death of her beloved husband, her in-laws confiscated all their properties that Bridget had laboured hard for.

Bridget is one of the founding beneficiaries of GHAPE, but she dropped out because of the death of her husband. Later on with a lot of courage, she joined again and has since then been very faithful with loan repayment due to her hard work. This is her fifth loan from GHAPE. She plans to invest her new loan in her old business of "buy and sell" and pig-rearing, poultry, and cultivation of yams and cocoyams.

Her business is going to succeed because there is a ready market for the animals and for her produce. Due to her longevity in this business, she is well known in her community for “buyam sellam” articles and has a lot of customers who come from far and near.

With the profits from this loan, she plans to continue paying her children's school fees and other educational needs. She hopes this loan will help her catch up with life and improve her family's standard of living.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying sweet yams, plantains, piglets and fowl and cultivation of yams and cocoyams

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala est composé de neuf (09) femmes ayant en moyenne 41ans et 4 enfants, toutes mariées et vivant majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques au quartier Bamanan kin de Markala préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Kotognontala s’est spécialisé dans le commerce de poisson et des condiments alimentaires .Après avoir correctement remboursé leur 1er prêt, ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt sera  utilisé pour acheter 10 paniers de poissons frais au bord du fleuve Niger, 500 sachets de glaces, 3 sacs de choux pommés, 4 sacs d’oignon et 2 sacs de sels iodés. Elles se  ravitaillent en poisson frais au bord du fleuve Niger, une partie de ce poisson est fumée à l’aide d’un fumoir et ou séchée. Les condiments sont achetés une fois par semaine à Siribala. Ces produits sont vendus à domicile, en ambulant et aux marchés de Kirango et de Diamarabougou (Markala) à une cliente composée de femmes et  d’hommes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et aider les maris à subvenir aux charges de la famille.
texts.en:
The Kotognontala group is composed of 9 women with an average age of 41 and on average, 4 children. They are all married and most of them live in big polygamous families in the Bamanan Kin district of Markala, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali). Kotognontala group members are specialized in selling fish and condiments. After having reimbursed their first loan correctly, this group is on their second group (solidarity) loan.

This loan will be used to buy 10 baskets of fresh fish along the banks of the Niger river, 500 bags of ice, 3 sacks of cabbages, 4 sacks of onions, and 2 sacks of iodized salt. They buy their fish along the banks of the Niger river, and then smoke or dry part of it. The condiments are purchased once a week in Siribala. These products are sold out of their houses, door-to-door, or in the marketplaces of Kirango and of Diamarabougou (Markala) to a clientele composed of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to help their husbands support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fish and condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo K. is 52 years old and lives with her niece in Battambang province, Cambodia. She is a widow who runs a small business selling fried bananas to the people in her community, earning around $3 each day. This loan will be used to help her expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Met

texts.en: Met H. is 45 years old, and lives with his wife in Battambang, Cambodia. He works as a moto-taxi driver and earns around $28 each day. His wife, pictured here, earns $5 by selling charcoal in the community. This couple lives with seven children, four of whom are students and one is a construction worker. Met H. is asking for a loan for his wife to purchase rice and charcoal for resale.

loans.use: To purchase rice and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Bo

texts.en: Bo M., 40, is married and lives with her husband in Battambang, Cambodia. She is a good housewife who stays at home looking after three school-aged children. Her husband, pictured here, works as a construction foreman and is able to make $4 every day. Mrs. Bo M. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will reduce the public transportation cost.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Sout

texts.en:
Sout D. is 39 years old and sells fruit in Battambang province, Cambodia. Her business has been around for about 8 years and she makes US$10 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a motor-taxi driver and makes about $5 per day as well. 

Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Sout D. is asking for a loan to invest in her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell. She sees this investment as an opportunity that will increase her daily income.

loans.use: To invest in her own fruit business.

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en:
Angeline is married to Richard and they have five children; she lives in Kobenyang-Bome, a small rural town about an hour outside of Bamenda, Cameroon. With this loan, Angeline plans to invest in cultivating food crops such as cassava and palm oil plantation and will buy feed for her pigs from previous loan investment from GHAPE.

This is Angeline's sixth loan; she has been a member of GHAPE since 2003. She has a great deal of experience in her business activities; however, her husband is more than willing to assist her in the management of the pigs and palm trees. The demand for palm oil for cooking is always high as it is a basic household necessity in her neighbourhood.

The profit from this loan will be used to pay her children's school fees. She will also invest much of her profit back into her business. The rest will be used to clothe her children well, provide medical assistance to her family, and feed her family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: pruning of palm trees, buying pig feed, clearing of farm for cassava

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq (05) membres du groupe Sabali sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne 48 ans et vivent majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques avec 5 enfants chacune dans le village de Zogofina préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de mariage dans le quartier et exercent en général le commerce de charbon de bois, de bois de chauffe et des céréales au moment des récoltes. 
C’est dans le souci d’avoir un fonds de commerce pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle que les membres du groupe se sont organisés pour intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Elles sont à leur 5ème prêt de groupe après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les 4 prêts précédents.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 200 sacs de charbon de bois et  22  chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elles se  ravitaillent en charbon et bois dans les villages de Togo, Konodimini et Sakebougou, parfois leurs fournisseurs viennent les ravitailler sur place au village. Les produits sont écoulés de façon  ambulante à travers la ville de  Ségou au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle composée  d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 44 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
 Elles ont pour ambition de faire l’élevage des ovins et caprins.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Sabali are all married women who average 48 years of age and live for the most part in large polygamous families with five children each in the village of Zogofina, Ségou prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of community and marriage in the district and generally do commerce in charcoal, firewood, and grain when it is harvest time.

Concerned about having the working capital for satisfying customer needs, the group members organized themselves three years ago to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their fifth group loan after having repaid the preceding four without difficulty. This new loan will be used to buy 200 sacks of charcoal and 22 cart loads of firewood. Supplies of charcoal are gotten in the villages of Togo, Konodimini, and Sakebougou. Sometimes the suppliers come and deliver to them locally. The goods are sold door-to-door throughout the city of Ségou, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of men and women.

They envision realizing an average monthly profit of 44,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest and to cover family expenses. Their ambition is to raise sheep and goats.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal and firewood

loans.name: Chheut

texts.en: Chheut S., 28, lives with his wife in Battambang, Cambodia. He has run a motor-taxi business since 2006 and is able to make $5 per day, while his wife, pictured here, makes $4 a day by selling fruit from home. This loan will be used to invest in the fruit business.

loans.use: To invest in fruit business.

loans.name: Soulayman

texts.en:
Soulayman is a 49-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Soulayman has been working in agriculture for twenty-one years. He plants and sells vegetables. His sells his produce to vegetable markets. When he first started his business, his land was small, and he didn’t have a greenhouse. He decided on this business because he learned it when he was young, and he wanted to increase his land.

He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua to purchase polyethylene (plastic covers) for the greenhouse and new tools for his work. Soulayman has been a microcredit client for six years and has always re-paid his loans on time. His previous loans helped him improve his business and his family's financiA. situation. In the future, he plans to expand his land and continue improving his business.

loans.use: Buy materials and tools for his business

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en:
Mouhamad is a 21-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon. Mouhamad has owned a coffee shop since 2007. He sells coffee, all kinds of hot beverages, and “nargileh” (also known as “shisha” in Egypt). Nargileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East, where a water pipe is used to smoke fruit flavored tobacco. Nargileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, Europe, and other countries. Mouhamad's business is special because he has experience in this domain and his coffee shop is like a second home. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Besides the coffee shop, Mouhamad works in a library.

When he first started his business, Mouhamad didn’t have the necessary start up capital, so he is requesting a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise for his coffee shop. This is the first time that Mouhamad has requested a loan. He plans on expanding his business in the future.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his coffee shop

loans.name: Timinandia (Persévérance) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Timinandia au nombre de cinq (05) ont en moyenne 27 ans et 3 enfants. Elles sont toutes mariées  et vivent dans des familles monogamiques dans le village de Sebougou  préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de voisinage et sont tous membres  de l’association traditionnelle d’entraide de l’ethnie bobo de Sebougou. Le besoin d’entre prendre des activités génératrices de revenus les a amené à chercher un appui ; Ainsi, elles ont été informées par l’association Djamadjigui de Sebougou sur les activités que mène Soro Yiriwaso avec les femmes. Elles intégrèrent de cette façon le programme du crédit l’institution avec qui elles sont à leur 1ier  prêt pour un montant de 250 000FCFA. Ce montant sera utilisé pour acheter 25  chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, 20 cartons de savon de marque hypo et un sac de savon à fabrication locale >. Elles sont ravitaillées en bois de chauffe permanemment à domicile par les exploitants et en  savon lors des jours de foires hebdomadaires de la ville de Ségou. Le bois de chauffe est fendu en morceaux et est vendu en tas à domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Quant au savon il est vendu par morceau de porte en porte dans le quartier au comptant et parfois à crédit payable quotidiennement.
Elles  envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 66 670FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser les intérêts du prêt, épargner et acheter des trousseaux de mariage pour leurs enfants. Leur objectif est d’avoir une charrette et un âne qui leur permettra de générer plus de ressources.
texts.en:
The members of the group Timinandia are five in number and average 27 years of age and three children. They are all married women and live in monogamous families in the village of Sebougou, Ségou prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members know one another through ties of marriage and community and are all members of the traditional mutual aid association of the Bobo ethnicity of Sebougou. The need to work to earn an income has brought them to seek support; and so, they were informed by the Djamadjigui association of Sebougou regarding the work that Soro Yiriwaso is doing with women. In this way, the women joined its loan program and are now on their first loan in the amount of 250,000 francs CFA. This money will be used to buy 25 cart loads of firewood, 20 boxes of Hypo brand soap, and a sack of locally-made soap. Supplies of firewood are continually gotten at home from producers; and the soap is gotten at the weekly fairs in the city of Ségou. The firewood is split into pieces and sold in piles at home, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed for the most part of women. As for the soap, it is sold by the piece door-to-door in the district, for cash and sometimes on credit payable the same day.

The group members envision realizing an average monthly profit of 66,670 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest, to save some money, and to buy wedding items and accessories for their children. Their objective is to have a cart and donkey that will enable them to generate more resources.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood and soap

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 25-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon with his wife. Houssein has owned an Internet shop for a year and a half. He also offers computer games and serves coffee. Houssein's business is special because he has a good relationship with his clients, who are his friends and neighbors.

When Houssein first started his business, he didn’t have the necessary start up capital. He went ahead with the business because he wanted to be independent. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase an Internet machine, so he can sell Internet services to individuals. This is the first time that Houssein has requested a loan. In the future, he plans on improving and expanding his business.

loans.use: Purchase an Internet machine

loans.name: Olish

texts.ru: Олиш  женат, имеет 6 сына и 2 дочек. Он зарабатывает тем, что выращивает  овощи  летом и осенью он продает дыню,  в конце зимы он сажает арахис. Его сыновья помогают в хозяйстве. Основной его бизнес  откорм скота. У него 6 коров и  20 овец, а также у него есть козы. В конце зимы в  отаре пополнение. В настоящее время скот подешевел, Олиш планирует прикупить несколько голов скота, ему не хватает оборотный капитал, в кишлаке все держат скот и некоторые из них получают кредит в Микроинвесте, они посоветовали  обратится в Микроинвест для получения займа. Он обратился, получив необходимую информацию ему вскоре предоставят займ.
texts.en:
Olish is married, he has six sons and two daughters. He makes his living by growing vegetables in the summer and selling melons in the fall, and in the end of winter he plants peanuts. His sons help him in this business. His main business is breeding cattle. He now has six cows and twenty sheep, and some goats as well. At the end of winter there's an addition to the livestock. Right now the prices are low for cattle. Olish plans to buy a few more heads of cattle, but there's not enough working capital. In his village everyone keeps livestock and some of them get loans from MicroInvest and they have advised him to apply at MicroInvest for a loan. Olish has come and received the necessary information and should soon get his loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cattle

loans.name: Fatina

texts.en:
Fatina is a 48-year-old divorced woman who lives in Beirut, capitA. of Lebanon. Fatina has owned a beauty salon for twenty-eight years. She sells cosmetics, perfumes, makeup, and beauty products, as well as provides beauty care services. Fatina's business is speciA. because she has good experience, takes good care of her clients, and uses good quality beauty products. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Fatina started her business after she got divorced because she needed money to support herself.

Fatina has been a microcredit client for seven years and has always repaid her loans on time. Her previous loans helped her improve her business and her family financiA. situation. This time Fatina has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua to purchase beauty products for her salon. In the future, she plans on writing a beauty book and expanding her business by opening a beauty institute.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Kanbèkoulou Group

texts.fr:
Les dix (10) membres du groupe Kanbèkoulou ont un âge moyen de 39 ans toutes mariées et vivant majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques dans la sous-préfecture de Markala (quatrième administrative région du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 5 enfants et se sont connues par des liens d’amitié et de voisinage. Elles sont issues de l’association  traditionnelle  Layidou.
Elles font essentiellement le commerce de condiments alimentaires. C’est le souci d’agrandir leurs fonds de commerce qu’elles ont intégré l’institution. Elles sont à leur 3ème prêt, qui  sera utilisé pour acheter 6 sacs de choux pommés, 4 paniers de tomates fraîches, 1 panier de piments frais, 5kgs de poivres et de soumbala, 5 cartons de poissons fumés et 1 sac d’arachide qui sera transformé en pâte d’arachide. Elles se  ravitaillent une fois par semaine à Markala et mensuellement à Dougabougou et Seribala. Tous ces produits sont vendus sur place à Diamarabougou Rail Ko au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 26 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Kanbèkoulou average 39 years of age and are all married women living for the most part in monogamous families in Markala sub-prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women have five children on average and know one another through ties of friendship and community. They come out of the tradition association Layidou and essentially do commerce in condiments.

Concerned about adding to their business capital, they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third loan, which will be used to buy 6 sacks of cabbage, 4 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 1 basket of fresh chili peppers, 5 kg of black pepper and soumbala (a condiment of pounded and fermented seeds), 5 boxes of smoked fish, and 1 sack of peanuts. Supplies are gotten once a week in Markala and monthly in Dougabougou and Seribala. All these goods are sold locally in Diamarabougou Rail Ko, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed mostly of women.

The group members plan on realizing an average monthly profit of 26,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest and to cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 44-year-old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Bassam has been selling mankoucheh for four years. Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Bassam decided on this business because he used to work in a bakery, where he gained lot of experience. Bassam's business is special because he makes such delicious mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors

Bassam has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase a motorcycle for his business, so he can start delivering mankoucheh. This is the first time that Bassam has asked for a loan. In the future, he plans to improve the décor of his shop.

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle for his business

loans.name: Amidou

texts.fr:
Mr Amidou S. est un homme marié, né vers 1968 à Ouogan (Sikasso) qui est  père de (05) enfants (2garçons et 3filles). Il vit dans une famille monogamme avec son épouse et ses enfants à Noumousso un des quartiers de Kadiolo ville(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge, il appris le commerce à côté de l’agriculture qu'il pratiquait avec ses parents comme activité première. Dépuis maintenant  7 ans la tendance s’est inversée, il vend dans sa boutique, de céréales et divers autres articles, dans le quartier Noumousso de la ville de Kadiolo au bord de la route principale. Il jouit d’une notorieté sans précédente dans la ville de kadiolo. 
Il collabore avec l’intitution de microfinanace Soro Yiriwaso il y a  2 ans. Il est à son 4eme prêt individuel, tous les précédents se sont bien dénoués.
Mr Amidou S. compte acheter avec son prêt 5 sacs de sucre, 10sacs de riz, 2sacs d’haricots, 5 bidons de 20 litres d’huile et 30 sacs de maïs. Il s’approvisionne à Kadiolo ville chez les grosssistes.
Mr Amidou S. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Il est souvent sollicité par certains fonctionnaires de la place pour leurs dotations mensuelles.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 94.000FCFA dont une partie sera injectée dans son commerce et l’autre partie sera mise de côté comme épargne. Il ambitionne d’être un grossiste.
texts.en:
Mr. Amidou S. is a married man, born about 1968 in Ouogan (Sikasso), who is a father of five children (two boys and three girls). He lives in a monogamous family with his wife and children in Noumousso, a district of Kadiolo (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). At a young age, he learned commerce along with agriculture, which he practiced with his parents as his first job. For seven years now, the trend has been inverted. In his shop located along the main road, he now sells grain and various other goods, in the Noumousso district of the city of Kadiolo, where he enjoys unprecedented fame.

He has been in collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for two years and is on his fourth individual loan. All the preceding loans have been settled. With this loan, he plans to buy 5 sacks of sugar, 10 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of beans, 5 drums (20 liters each) of cooking oil, and 30 sacks of corn. Supplies are gotten in Kadiolo City from wholesalers. Sales are made, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of women and men. He is often in demand by some local civil servants for their monthly allocation.

He envisions realizing an average monthly profit of 94,000 francs CFA, part of which will be injected into his business and the other will be put aside as savings. His ambition is to be a wholesaler.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, beans, rice, cooking oil, sugar, and various other goods

loans.name: Ambe Anna

texts.en:
Anna N. was married to Fuh Geofred and had four children. She is now divorced from her husband due to matrimonial problems. She is a very hard-working lady from childhood as she has proven beyond doubt in managing and taking care of the kids despite the hard and harsh nature of her husband that caused them now to be apart. Being a businesswoman, she had been working hard and taking care of the children as concerns their school needs and other necessities for them even before her divorce.

This is her fifth time requesting a loan from GHAPE. Her previous loans have been well managed and utilized. The most recent one was used for embroidering dresses and bed sheets, poultry and pig farming. Anna has confidence in this business because there is a high demand for foodstuffs and goods that are imperishable last for a long time. She promised to used the profit from the loan in educating her children and buy a plot for herself and increase the management capital.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buying beans, corn, and transportation

loans.name: Mankaa Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is married to Jonathan and they have six children. She is a very hard-working woman as far as maintaining and bringing up the family is concerned. She and her husband are committed in working together for the upkeep of the family. She has also proved her efforts in helping her husband pay the school fees for the children. She has also been able to toil and till the soil to feed the family though with some difficulties as invaders come in at times and destroy her farm produce which now makes her to work extra hard selling food and in her provision store.

Cecilia has taken loan from GHAPE four times already. This is the fifth time she wants a loan from GHAPE. She knows this business will succeed because it is a business she has been doing for a long time and so she has a lot of customers. We do eat to survive and serving the community with cooked food more souls and lives will live to survive which will help the clan to grow from strength to strength.

The profit from her loan will be used to further her children's education and also improve the living standards of her family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buying beans, corn, and transportation

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Mr Siaka KONE est âgé de 36 ans et  vit dans une famille monogame avec son épouse et ses trois enfants  à Noumousso un des quartiers de Kadiolo ville(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Il n’a jamais été à l’école, il a grandi à côté de ses parents comme cultivateur (il possède plus de 5 ha de champ qu’il cultive pendant l’hivernage) et a appris à faire le commerce de céréales au file  des années.  Actuellement, il a un magasin dans le quartier Noumousso de la ville de Kadiolo en face de la route principale  non loin du marché où il vend des céréales et du ciment depuis 3 ans.  
Il est à sa deuxième  prêt individuel  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le précédent s’étant bien dénoué. 
Mr Siaka KONE compte acheter avec son prêt 1tonne de maïs, 5 sacs de mil et 30 sacs de ciment. Il s’approvisionne en Côte D’Ivoire pays frontalier du Mali, et à Kadiolo  ville (préfecture de la 3eme région administrative du Mali) et dans les villages  environants. Mr Siaka KONE vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée en général d’hommes. 
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75.000FCFA dont une partie  sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie en épargne. Il ambitionne d’être un grossiste.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Koné, 36, lives in a monogamous family with his wife and his three children in Noumousso, a district of the town of Kadiolo (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He was never able to go to school; he grew up with his parents as a farmer (he owns 5 hectares that he farms in the rainy season) and over the years, he learned to sell cereals. Presently, he has a store in the Noumousso district of the town of Kadiolo across from the main road, not far from the market, and he has been selling cereals and cement there for 3 years.

He is on his second individual loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, having correctly reimbursed the first loan. He does his buying in Côte D’Ivoire, a country that borders Mali, and in Kadiolo (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and the surrounding villages. Mr. Siaka Koné sells for cash and on credit to a clientele composed mostly of men.

He hopes to make an average monthly profit of 75,000 F CFA of which part will be used to increase his working capital and part will be saved. His ambition is to become a wholesaler.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of corn (maize), millet, and cement

loans.name: Golibjon

texts.en:
Golibjon A. is a very hard-working and enterprising man. He cultivates farmland and cares for his animals to earn a living. It is because of his animals that he earns his daily bread, so he tries to take care of them as best he can.

Golibjon is one of the most dedicated farmers. Every morning the town sees him walk to work. He is one of the most respected people in the area and he is an example for his children and the rest of the town. The hardwork he dedicates to farming and his devotion is what stands out. Nonetheless, he has difficulties and financial problems which he has to overcome. Therefore, he is requesting your help. He needs a loan of 3500 Somoni to purchase seeds and fertilizer so he can increase his production.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history. Its history includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and many famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets like Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.en:
Gulnora H. is the humble mother of a family with two children. She works hard to educate her children. She works in agriculture, along with her husband of 11 years to generate the family’s income. They work hard at growing corn and wheat, which they sell in the market. Last season was very good, and after much effort, they achieved a big harvest. Her husband sold their harvest in the market.

Currently Gulnora’s family has a financial problem and she needs help. The family would like to continue planting corn and wheat and also increase their capital so they can buy more in seed and fertilizer.
