Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand her business

loans.name: Issiah

texts.en:
Issiah A. sells mobile phone cards and agriculture tools and implements at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. Issiah has received junior high education. He is married and has 4 dependents. His wife is a petty trader.

Issiah has been selling mobile phone cards and agriculture tools and implements since 2001. He is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of mobile phone cards, agricultural tools, and implements to meet the increase in demand by his customers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest for the expansion of his business in mobile phone cards and agricultural tools.

Beside him in the photograph are the mobile phone cards packed in the box for sale.

loans.use: additional capital to increase the sale of phone cards, etc.

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
Jamshed E. is 30 years old. He is married with four children. Jamshed has been selling clothing for 10 years. He began selling to acquaintances and friends, and after a while he realized that he had a lot of customers. So, he decided to rent a shop and establish himself in “Ganjina” market.

Jamshed is a very enterprising man with a great desire to get ahead. His business has been able to show the fruits of his labor and he hopes to grow as a businessman. Jamshed needs a loan of 600 USD, which he plans to invest in inventory in order to offer better service and variety to his customers. You can be an important part of the growth of this business. Today is your opportunity to help, have no doubt!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing his working capital with the purpose of development of business.

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en: N. Farida is one of the executive members of the Mumuwa loan group in Mpigi. She is a very hardworking lady.  Although she is not married, she helps to care for four children. She sells bananas for a living, which she grows on her farm or buys from wholesalers.  She also has farms mairungi, a delicacy enjoyed by mostly men in different parts of Kampala. She supplies traders in Kikuubo, Owino and Katwe with her produce, and this has helped her pay school fees for her dependents. Farida is requesting a loan to restock her inventory of bananas and pay for labor to clear her land for another season.

loans.use: to buy more bananas and pay workers to clear her land for plantings

loans.name: Munavar

texts.en: I. Munavar is 59 years old. She is married and has a son who is also married. Munavar’s husband works on at beneficent organization as an accountant.  In order to support her husband Munavar has been running her own business already for 9 years. She is selling the national trousers for women. The national dresses and trousers in Tajikistan are very popular and very important item of the majority of women and girls. Munavar has the trading place in the center local markets of Dushanbe city. She is trying to have wide range of goods to able to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of the clients with different levels of income.  Munavar requests $800 with the purpose to purchase the trousers for women in order to increase the range of goods. She promises to repay the loan within 6 months.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new national trousers for women for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en:
For the past twelve years, Mavlyuda has sold men’s clothing at the “Ganjina” market in Dushanbe. Mavlyuda is a married mother of four children. She is determined to provide a better life for entire family. Mavlyuda is hard working and kind, giving her the ideal blend of entrepreneurial determination and service. Skilled in trade and abounding in character, Mavlyuda has both a strong business base and a perfect credit history with IMON International. Currently, she is seeking a loan of $600 to purchase a new vending facility and expand her business. With this increased income, Mavlyuda plans to continue her business growth and to improve the financial situation of her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and its famous thinkers and philosophers. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BCE. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is the poorest of the former Soviet republics. When the nation declared independence from the U.S.S.R., a civil war ignited and further damaged an already weakened economy. 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These difficult conditions have resulted in high levels on unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, such as Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To improve and expand her business

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna A. sells used clothing at the Nyankumasi market near Cape Coast. Edna has received senior high education.  She is married and has 3 children. Edna has been selling used clothing since 2005. She is responsible for helping her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of  her business in used clothing.

loans.use: additional capital to  increase the sale of used clothing

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en: Margaret N. is the leader of the Bbogo loan group in Lugazi. She is a very hard working lady and manages her businesses well.  She sells a small silvery fish known as ‘mukene’ that she buys from the fishermen either late at night or very early in the morning depending on the fishing schedule and season.  She then sells these fish to people at the landing site, in the village, and others in Lugazi.  In addition to this business, she makes chapattis for customers for breakfast.  Her sales depend on the weather, on some days she can use up to 1.5 packets of flour.  Lastly, she has a small scale farm. Margaret is requesting a loan to buy more fish to sell and a carton of flour.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell and a carton of flour

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en: N. Mary is the leader and a founding member of the Kyakuwa group in Senyi. She is married with 6 children. She cares for them as well as two other relatives, and pays for the schooling of all of them. Mary farms and sells bananas and her other crops at the local market. She is requesting a loan to increase her kiosks inventory, and to increase the production of her farm.

loans.use: increasing inventory, and farming production

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua T. sells personal products and food supplies like maize at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. Akua has received junior high education. She is a single parent and has 2 children.

Akua has been selling personal products and food supplies since 2008. She is responsible for paying family expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of food supplies to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to developing her farm.

loans.use: additional capital to  increase the sale of food supplies

loans.name: George

texts.en: George K. sells frozen fish at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. George has received junior high education.  He is married and has 3 children. His wife is a petty trader. George has been selling frozen fish for about 3 years. He is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . His loan will be used as additional capital to enable to him increase the sale of frozen fish to meet the increase in demand by his customers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to invest in his oil palm plantation.

loans.use: additional capital to increase the sale of frozen fish

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
At 64, Marilyn is active in managing her small business selling commercial feeds in her village.  She is married to Orlando, a farmer, and they have four children: Steven, 23, a graduate with his Bachelor of Science in Information Technology; Jess Angelo, 18, a two-year course graduate; Almajhoan, 10, fourth-grade student and Orlando Jr., 7, a first-grader.  They live a simple life in the mountainous village of Cabisera 27 Hacienda San Antonio Ilagan, Isabela. 

Marilyn wanted to request a loan amounting to PHP6,000.00, which she intends to invest in her business. She is also planning to put up a small village store if she still has extra capital.  However, her main priority at the moment is to utilize the loan to buy sacks of feed for her business and rice mill.  She hopes to improve her business and to sustain their resources for the benefit of her children.  She also hopes to continue to support her children's studies.  She said that, in order to achieve this, they need to work harder.

loans.use: To buy sacks of feed

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia T. operates a vegetable vending business in her rural village at Cabisera 14-16 Ilagan, Isabela. She roams around the village to sell different kinds of vegetables. With the business, Amelia is able to generate an income of PHP750 weekly. She is thankful that through it, she is able to help her husband with their financial and basic needs. She hopes to develop her vending business into a more organized and stable source of income by perseverance. Thus, Amelia is requesting a loan amounting to PHP5,000.00 to be used in venturing into this type of business. 

She is a person who is willing to extend help to others when necessary and depends on her own capabilities. Amelia is 32 years old and married to Rodolfo T., who assists her in the business by planting different kinds of vegetables, which she will later sell. They were blessed with two children: Rose Ann Jelly, 12; and Hazel Joy, 9. Both are in the primary level of education in a public school situated in their village. Amelia is hoping that someday, despite their poor living conditions, they will be able to support their children’s education through their business.

loans.use: For capital for business expansion

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa is a village store owner who has been managing her business for almost a year and it really helps her in meeting the needs of her children.  She would like to borrow a loan of PHP 4,000.00 that she will to use to expand her business. She is planning to purchase additional merchandise for her store such as garlic, onions, bottled soft drinks, canned goods and so on.  She will do her best to help her husband earn money for their immediate needs and education of their four children.

Elisa is 33 years old and married to Isidro, a driver for Petron Company based in Hilltop, Naguillan, Isabela.  They are blessed with four kids: Ariel, 12, already in grade six; Arnie, 11, grade five; Alvin John, 4, and Isidro Jr., 2.  Despite the difficulties, they always do their best to be successful.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise to sell in her store

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda, 54 years old, is married to Antonio and they have three children: Richard, 15, in his fourth year of high school; Avelino, 19, a graduate and Edie, 22, also a graduate.  They are happily living in their distant and mountainous place. 

Criseda is raising hogs in their village as their alternative source of income since upland farming is their major source of income.  To assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family, Criselda is now asking for a loan of PHP5,000 to maintain her hog raising business and also to help her husband in purchasing farm necessities. 

She keeps on working to improve her business. She is thankful that she was given an opportunity to seek financial assistance, and she is praying that her loan request will be granted. She said that she must strive for more and always put God in everything that she does.

loans.use: To maintain their hog raising business and purchase farm necessities

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret A. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Margret sells groceries, clothing, plastics, etc. at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2005. Her husband is a petty trader.

Margret uses her income to help her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Margret will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of groceries, clothing and plastics to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Margret plans to reinvest for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: additional capital to increase the sale of groceries, etc.

loans.name: Eben

texts.en:
Eben O. B. is married and has 2 children. He has received schooling through senior high. Eben sells groceries and other food supplies at Nyankumasi post office near Cape Coast, which he has done for about 4 years. His wife is a petty trader.

Eben uses his income to pay for the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Eben will use the loan to purchase more groceries to meet the increase in demand by his customers. With the new profits from his expanded business, Eben plans to reinvest for the expansion of his business selling groceries.

loans.use: purchase more groceries to meet the increase in demand

loans.name: Benkadi  (L’ Entente). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi de l’association Dembagnouma est constitué de cinq femmes toutes mariées vivant dans des foyers en majorité polygames dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala, région de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles cohabitent ensemble depuis très longtemps et ont en moyenne 30 ans et 3 enfants. Elles mènent  comme activité principale la vente d’ arachide et sa transformation en pâte. En plus, elles font également la vente d’habits pour enfant. Elles ont de l’expérience dans la transformation de l’arachide et le commerce d’habits.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso.Le groupe Benkadi est à son premier prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe).
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour achéter des sacs d’arachide et des habits pour enfants  qui seront  revendus  au marché ou de porte en porte. Elles vendent généralement au comptant et en détail à une clientèle constituée de toutes les catégories sociales.
Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 55 000 F CFA de bénéfice chacune au cours de ce cycle. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
 Dans l’avenir, le groupe compte obtenir  un prêt élévé pour pouvoir diversifier les activités.
texts.en:
This Benkadi group belonging to the Dembagnouma association is made up of 5 married women who live in mostly polygamous families in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Koutiala, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have been living together for a very long time and have an average age of 30 with, on average, 3 children. Their main business is selling peanuts and transforming them into peanut butter. Besides that, they also sell outfits for children. They have experience in producing peanut butter and in selling clothing.

With the intention of expanding their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. The Benkadi group is on their very first solidarity loan (group loan). This loan will be used to buy sacks of peanuts and clothing for children that will be re-sold at the market or door-to-door. They generally sell for cash and retail, to a clientele composed of all sorts of people.

With this loan, they each expect to make on average 55,000 F CFA in profit during the loan cycle. This profit will be used to reimburse the loan and help support their families. In future, the group hopes to obtain a bigger loan so that they can diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts and clothing for children

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy T. is a single parent and has 2 children. She has received schooling through senior high. Nancy sells groceries and plastic products at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is a petty trader.

Nancy uses her income to pay for the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Nancy will use the loan to purchase more groceries and plastic products to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nancy plans to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: purchase more groceries and plastic products for re-sale

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Danaya de l’association Badegna sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 3 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage.
Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de condiments alimentaires (Soumbala un condiment à base de noix de néré très apprécié par les maliens).En plus de cette activité principale, elles vendent également des habits. 
Pour satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Danaya a décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des sacs de noix de néré à un prix abordable dans des villages  de Dogonasso, Koro barrage   et  Molobala. Quant aux habits, ils sont achetés à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Les soumbala sont vendus en gros au marché  de Bamako et c’est de là qu’elles s’approvisionnent en habillement qui est vendu de porte  en porte à la maison et au marché de koutiala. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen 120 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six women of the Danaya group belonging to the Badegna association are all married. They have an average age of 35 and on average, 3 children, and live in big traditional extended families in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of living in the same neighborhood. They have almost the same business, selling a condiment ("Soumbala" a condiment made from "néré" tree seeds, which is much loved by Malians). Besides this main business, they also sell clothing. To satisfy the needs of their ever-growing clientele, the Danaya group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. They intend to use this loan to buy sacks of néré seeds at a reasonable price in the villages of Dogonasso, Koro Barrage, and Molobala. As for the clothing, they buy it in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). The "soumbala" is sold wholesale in the market at Bamako and it is there that they stock up on clothing which is sold door-to-door, out of their homes, and in the market at Koutiala. They each hope to make an average profit of 120,000 F CFA during the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to repay the loan and to cover the expenses of their extended families, with any remainder invested in their business capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments and clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort G. is married and has 3 children. She has received no formal education. Comfort sells groceries and other food supplies at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2007. Her husband is a petty trader. Comfort uses her income to help her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family.

Comfort will use the loan to purchase more groceries to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to reinvest for the expansion of her business selling groceries.

loans.use: purchase more groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Kyei

texts.en: Kyei B. sells groceries and other food supplies in Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. Kyei has received a junior high school education.  He is married and has 3 children. Kyei has been selling groceries and other food supplies since 2006. He is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. He will use his loan to buy more groceries and bags of rice, cartons of cooking oil and other food items to meet the recent increase in demand. He hopes to reinvest the profits from his business in the further expansion of his store.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy more groceries and bags of rice, cartons of cooking oil and other food items to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Nichitici

texts.en: V. is 60 years old and lives in the Calarasi district of Tibirica village. Since her childhood, she has liked to help her parents with vegetables, seeds, and cultivation. Therefore, she decided to enter the same business. At this moment, she wants to extend her business in order to gain more profit for her family. Ms. Nichitici has been in the business for more than 10 years and she likes her job. V. has 10 hectares of arable lands that bring her a very good amount of products, but now she needs to irrigate and process the land to make it more fertile. The purpose of the loan is to buy fuel and seeds. We hope the loan borrowed by MicroInvest will help V. to extend her business.

loans.use: seeds and fuel purchase

loans.name: Edmund

texts.en: Edmund D. is married and has 2 children. He has received schooling through senior high. Edmund sells groceries and other food supplies at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast, which he has done since 2001. His wife is a trader and uses his income to pay for the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . Edmund will use the loan to purchase more groceries and bags of rice, cooking oil and other food items to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from his expanded business, Edmund plans to reinvest back for the expansion of  his trade in groceries.

loans.use: Edmund will use the loan to purchase more groceries and bags of rice, cattons of cooking oil and other food items to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Rosario vive en casa de sus padres en la calle 4 de mayo de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que realiza es la venta de comida en una tienda ubicada en su mismo domicilio y con esta actividad ella se mantiene y puede cubrir sus gastos de alimentación y vivienda.

El crédito que solicita es para compra de insumos como ser arroz, fideo, y otros en cantidad para de esta manera obtener mejores costos e incrementar sus volúmenes de  ingresos.

Es cliente de impro desde el año 2006 esta es la segunda vez que solicita crédito a través de Kiva. Su historial de  pagos es  muy bueno y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Rosario lives in her parents’ home in the city of La Paz. The activity that she carries out is the sale of food in a shop located in her home; with this activity she supports herself and is able to cover her expenses of food and housing. The loan that she requests is to purchase supplies such as rice, noodles, and others, in bulk to be able to obtain better costs and to increase the volume of her income. Rosario has been a client of Impro since 2006, and this is the second time that she has requested a loan through Kiva. Her payment history is very good and she is approved for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, noodles, and others supplies wholesale to reduce costs in her food sale business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora Maria vive en casa de su padre en la calle Munaypata de la zona 14 de septiembre de la ciudad de La Paz, esta separada del esposo y tiene una niña de 12 años de edad, que vive con ella.  La actividad que realiza es la venta de juguetes, tiene un puesto en su propia casa pero además tiene un puesto de venta en la calle Uyustus lugar donde se realizan ferias los días miércoles, sábados y domingos.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar más juguetes, aumentar su capital y de esta manera poder mejorar sus ingresos y seguir manteniendo a su familia.

Esta es la primera vez que solicita crédito de Impro y en análisis de su flujo de caja y el carácter emprendedor de  su  actividad la califican para obtener dicho crédito.
texts.en:
Maria lives in her father's house on Munaypata Street, in the community of "14 de septiembre" and in the city of La Paz. She is separated from her husband and she has a 12 year old daughter who lives with her. She makes a living by selling toys. She has a stand that she operates out of her home and another on Uyustus Street where there are bazars on Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays.

The loan that she is requesting will be used to buy more toys and to increase her business' capital. This way she will be able to improve her earnings and continue supporting her family.

This is the first time that she is requesting a loan from Impro. She has been approved for this loan based on the history of her business' profits and her work ethic.

(Translated by Mariela of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Toys to Sell

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua E. sells groceries and other food supplies, at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. Akua received a primary education, but unfortunately had to stop. She is married, and currently has two children. Her husband works as a trader. Akua has been vending groceries and other food supplies since 2005. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying for the rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses. Akua plans to use her loan to purchase more groceries, rice, cartons of cooking oil, and other food items to meet the increased demands of her customers. She hopes to use these profits to reinvest for expansion and increase the reach of her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more groceries and bags of rice, cattons of cooking oil and other food items for sale and also for the preparation of food for sale to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Ahliman

texts.en: Ahliman was born in 1971. This man is married, has 2 children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. He has been in sheep breeding business for 10 years. His minimum net profit is 150 AZN. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy 20 pregnant sheep. After 6 monthes he plans to sell the lambs of these sheep for buying the pregnant sheep and so he will increase the number of his sheep. He wishes to raise the number of his sheep to 50 and more.

loans.use: To purchase sheep to expand his business

loans.name: Grusca

texts.en: Ms. Grusca is 64 years old and she lives in Chisinau City in Republic of Moldova. For S. it's very difficult to survive there because her whole life she lived in the village and agriculture was the main activity to gain a profit. In Chisinau S. has a garden where she can cultivate cereals and vegetables. All the harvest she gets after her work she sells her produce at a market in Chisinau City. The purpose of the loan is to increase working capital.

loans.use: to increase working capital

loans.name: Juan Alberto

texts.es: El señor Juana Alberto Hernández tiene la edad de 45 años,  habita en el barrio San Caralampio ubicado en la Concepción  junto a su esposa es comerciante, ellos tiene a su cargo dos hijos los que estudian su primaria; los planes hacia su familia es lograr comprar un terreno para poder hacer la infraestructura de su taller. El desde hace diecinueve años trabaja como mecánico electricista, con sus propios esfuerzos a logrado mantenerlo. El solicita financiamiento para poder incrementar su negocio en la compra de herramientas ya que el negocio tiene  demanda y quiere captar clientes para que un futuro sus hijos se integren a trabajar con él. Para que puedan ser hombres de bien.
texts.en:
Mr. Juana Alberto Hernández is 45 years old, lives in the neighborhood called San Caralampio, in Concepcion, and together with his wife. They are merchants and have two children in their care who study in primary school. Their plan for the family is to be successful in buying a tract of land where they could have the infrastructure for a shop. For 19 years he has worked as a electrical mechanic, and with his own strength has been able to maintain the business. He is asking for finances to be able to improve his business through buying tools that the business demands, and he wants to get more clients so that one day, his children will be able to work alongside him, so they can be good men.

Translated from Spanish by Misty McNally, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools for his mechanic shop

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is married, and has one child. She attended school up until junior high, but unfortunately had to stop. Josephine currently sells clothing and fabric, and works as a seamstress who specializes in sewing women’s garments at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. She has worked in her job for around 12 years.

Josephine’s husband works as a trader, and they use their incomes together to pay rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses of the family.

Josephine will use her loan to purchase a larger variety of fabrics, to expand her client base and business range. She will use her additional income to also expand a plot of land near her house to set up a family home for additional members.

loans.use: To expand her business and support her family

loans.name: Karla Ivette

texts.es: La joven Karla Ivette González Nuñes tiene la edad de 22 años, habita en el reparto Juan Ramón Padilla junto a sus padres,  es soltera, estudia actualmente derecho, los planes hacia un futuro es llegar a culminar su carrera para poder apoyarle a sus padres, y sentirse una profesional, se desempeña como secretaria en un bufete jurídico. Y solicita financiamiento ya que tiene que comprar unos libros y los gastos en la universidad y no desea retrasar sus estudios, ya que con lo que gana es poco es por eso que desea culminar su carrera para optar por un buen puesto y ganar bien. Este financiamiento es el segundo en Afodenic lo cual es de mucho beneficio en lo personal ya que esta realizando sus sueños en poder lograr salir adelante con sus estudios.
texts.en:
Young Karla Ivette González Nuñes is 22 years old, lives in the sub-division Juan Ramón Padilla with her parents, is single, and is currently studying law. Her future plans are to finish her academic studies to be able to support her parents, and to feel like a professional. She is currently a secretary at a law firm. She is requesting a loan because she needs to purchase books and has university expenses. She does not wish to delay her studies given that what she earns is very little and because of this she wishes to finish her studies so that she can apply to a good job and ear well. This loan will be her second with Afodenic, which is of much personal benefit given that she is realizing her dreams in being able to get ahead with her studies.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase books and pay for university expenses.

loans.name: Asif

texts.en:
Asif was born in 1978. This man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs.

He has run this business for 5 years. His net profit minimum is 50 AZN per month. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables.

In the future after improving his business, he would like to build a shop and to buy a lot of sorts of fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther T. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Esther sells sewing materials and footwear at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1989. Her husband is a trader. Esther uses her income to support her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family.

Esther will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of footwear and sewing materials to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to reinvest for the expansion of her trade in footwear and sewing materials.

loans.use: To increase the sale of footwear and sewing materials to meet the increase in demand by her customers

loans.name: La Union Hacia La Fuerza Group

texts.en:
Ramona operates a small restaurant inside her home. The menu varies daily dependent upon what is available, but daily a “plato del día”, or plate of the day, is offered generally consisting of rice, beans and a meat option, or sancocho, a typical Dominican stew. Aided by Esperanza International, Ramona is able to purchase ingredients in greater bulk and produce a larger quantity of food for her customers and in turn, earn a greater profit than she was able to before her first loan.

Ramona is not alone in her quest to earn a profit through entrepreneurial activities. Ramona is a member of the ten person microfinance bank, “La Union Hacia La Fuerza”. This group’s past two loans have been successfully repaid, and the group, including Ramona, hopes to utilize a third loan for further business expansion.

Ramona, mother of four children (ages 9, 11, 12, and 14), desires to see growth in her business so that she may continually provide for her children. Her husband, a street vegetable vender, desires the same and together, success is aspired for.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for restaurant

loans.name: Shukufa

texts.en: Shukufa (her husband is pictured) is a mother of 5 children. She was born in 1965. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Bala Bahmanli village. Shukufa has been in a cattle breeding business for 10 years. Now, she and her husband need a loan of 950 AZN to buy 2 calves.

loans.use: To buy 2 calves

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth D. sells groceries and other food supplies in Katakyiasi near Cape Coast. She has completed an education up to junior high school. Elizabeth is now married and has three children. Her husband is a trader. She is responsible for supporting him with the rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses of the family. Elizabeth has been selling groceries and other food supplies for 30 years now. Her loan will be used to buy more groceries, bags of rice, cartons of cooking oil, and other food items to meet the increasing demand of her customers. Elizabeth hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in the expansion of her trade in groceries.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her grocery selling business

loans.name: Maxima Maria

texts.es:
La Señora Máxima María O. Martínez tiene la edad de 33 años, su estado civil es casado, Doña Máxima tiene 2 hijos sus edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 8 años cursa recientemente el 5 grado de primaria su otro hijo de 5 años cursa el 2 grado de primaria, su compañero de vida labora como obrero, sus propósitos son de engrandecer su negocio con el fin de mantener este trabajo por que es que mas le ha gustado, sus sueños son de obtener su propio negocio para proporcionar mas ingresos a su familia ya que no puede descansar por lo que no puede descuidar su negocio ya que sin el no podría proporcionarle a sus hijos lo que necesitan ya que sus intereses son trabajar fuerte para logra sus metas propuestas por lo que su familia le dado el apoyo necesario, sus deseos son que otros países nos ayuden económicamente ya que somos un país muy pobre y el interés que muestran los países industrializados para ayudar en algo es muy bueno ya que nicaragua es uno de los países mas pobres.

La actividad económica a la que Doña Máxima se dedica es la venta de cosméticos y ropa en general, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, Doña Máxima es una trabajadora del ministerio de educación  pero los ingresos que provenían de este salario son muy pocos por lo que no le ajustaba para cancelar los compromisos de su hogar por lo que por cuenta propia decide realizar la venta de cosméticos con sus compañeros de trabajo y también realizaba la venta de estos productos en la casa de habitación de amigos por lo que al inicio no poseía mucha experiencia en la venta de los productos y trato de buscar la posibilidad de aprender pero no le fue tan difícil por lo que busco la relación de la experiencia de dar clases con sus alumnos que fue casi la misma y así logra su practica  en la venta de sus productos ya que cuando ofertaba el producto lo hacia con timidez pero logro desenvolverse en este negocio y al paso del tiempo tomo cariño de a este negocio que era su otro medio de vida por lo que ahora el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo propuesto para los productos necesarios que sus clientes le realizan de encargos para que después pueda distribuirlos y conseguir lo necesario para su familia.
texts.en:
Maxima Maria O. M., 33, is married and the mother of 2 children. Her older son is 8 years old and just started the 5th grade and her younger son is 5 years old and in the 2nd grade. Her husband is a laborer. Her purpose is to grow her business with the goal of maintaining the work that has given her great pleasure. She needs her own business because her family needs the income from it. She can't rest because if she doesn't take care of the business she won't be able to provide her children with the things that they need. She hopes that people in other countries will help Nicaraguans because Nicaragua is a very poor country and the interest that people in industrialized countries show in helping the people there is a very good thing.

Maxima operates a business selling cosmetics and clothing. There's no fixed address for the business. She's operated it for 3 years. Even though Maxima works for the Ministry of Education, her income there isn't enough to cover the family's expenses and, consequently, she decided to sell cosmetics with some friends at work. She also sells her products at the houses of friends. She didn't have much sales experience when she started but, as it turned out, the experience she'd gained teaching her students was very much like what she needed for selling. She was shy at first but she managed to get by and, with time, came to love the business that was her other means of making a living. This loan is for working capital. Maxima will use it to buy the products that her customers have charged her with buying so that she can get the things her family needs.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya de l’association Jiguitougou est composé de quatre femmes mariées et deux célibataires. Les membres ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Hamdallaye de la  ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens  de voisinage. Elles exercent  presque la même activité de vente de bois de chauffe et  la fabrication artisanale de savons qu’elles ont appris à bas âge auprès de leur maman qui pratiquait  ce métier. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Danaya a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son quatrième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des chargements de camions en bois de chauffe, des barriques de déchets d’huile de coton et une grande quantité de soude caustique (pour la fabrication du savon). Elles s’approvisionnent en bois de chauffe dans les villages de  Welinguena et Belesso. Quant aux ingrédients du savon, ils sont achetés au marché de koutiala. Le bois de chauffe est vendu à la maison, le savon  est vendu en détail au marché  de Koutiala et à la  maison. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen 70 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
 NB : Fatou Fané est absente de la photo, elle vient d’accoucher.
texts.en:
This Danaya group belonging to the Jiguitougou association is composed of four married women and two who are still single. The members have an average age of 27 and on average, 3 children and they live in big traditional extended families in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know each other because of living in the same area. They mostly have the same business: selling firewood and making homemade soap whose fabrication they learned when they were quite young from their mothers who had mastered this trade.

In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing clientele, the Danaya group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy some truckloads of firewood, some barrels of cotton oil waste, and a big quantity of caustic soda (used in soap-making). They buy their firewood in the villages of Welinguena et Belesso. As for the ingredients for soap-making, they buy those at the Koutiala market. The firewood is sold out of their homes; the soap is sold retail in the market of Koutiala and from their homes.

They each hope to make an average profit of 70,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle; this money will be used to make repayments on the loan and support their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Note: Fatou Fané is absent from the photo because she had just given birth.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood and fabrication of soap for re-sale

loans.name: Bunyad

texts.en:
Bunyad (his wife is pictured) is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in Bala Bahmanli village.

5 years ago, they decided to start their cattle breeding business. Now they need a loan of 950 AZN to buy 2 calves to improve their cattle breeding business.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves

loans.name: Victoria Group

texts.en:
“Victoria”, or Victory, is a group of five entrepreneurs, mostly illiterate, seeking their seventh loan with Esperanza International.  This group’s past six loans have been successfully repaid through business expansion and the group hopes to utilize a seventh loan to continue such expansion. Juan is the coordinator of this group in the city of El Seybo.

Juan, father of three (ages: 30, 25, 20), operates assorted men’s and women’s clothing and undergarment sales.  Aided by his six previous loans, Juan has seen growth in the availability of product offerings and an increase in his profit margin.  Juan desires to continue to provide for his family and to witness continued success and growth in his clothing business.  

Other members of Juan’s bank run similar entrepreneurial operations including bean and vegetable sales and two “colmados”, or grocery stands.  

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Increase clothing inventory and sales

loans.name: Fokaben  (L’ Entente). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Fokaben est constitué de huit femmes toutes mariées vivant dans des foyers en majorité polygames dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans et 3 enfants. Elles mènent  comme activité principale la vente d’ arachide sous plusieurs formes (grillé ou pâte) et en plus, des condiments. Elles ont de l’expérience dans la transformation de l’arachide et la vente de condiments.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis bientôt deux ans.  Après avoir correctement remboursé tous les deux premiers prêts qui étaient de 50 000 F CFA et 75 000 F CFA par membre, le groupe Fokaben est à son troixième prêt solidaire de 100 000 F CFA par membre (prêt de groupe).
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour achéter des sacs d’arachide et divers condiments alimentaires qui seront  revendus à la  maison, au marché ou de porte en porte. Elles vendent généralement au comptant en détail à une clientèle constituée de femmes.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 110 000 CFA de bénéfice chacune au cours de ce cycle. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Fokaben group is made up of eight women, all married and living in mostly polygamous households in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Koutiala, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have an average age of 32 and on average, 3 children. Their principal business is selling peanuts in various forms (roasted or as peanut butter) and also condiments. They have experience in making peanut butter and in selling condiments.

Wishing to expand their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. After having correctly reimbursed their two previous loans which amounted to 50,000 F CFA and 75,000 F CFA per member, the Fokaben group is on its third solidarity loan of 100,000 F CFA per member (a group loan).

This loan will be used to buy sacks of peanuts and various condiments which will be re-sold out of their houses, at the market, and door-to-door. They generally sell retail and for cash to a clientele constituted of women.

With this new loan, they each expect to make on average 110,000 CFA in profit in the course of this loan cycle. This profit will be used to reimburse the loan and cover current household expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts and condiments for re-sale
